comments.commentBody: Actually, a recent fix now permits such shopping/browsing on healthcare.gov. It's quite user friendly and requires no personal identifiers, which browsers are reluctant to give. When the browser is ready to purchase, he/she is directed to the purchasing website.

Allowing people to look at plans without registering would be a huge improvement. It would also be good politically, allowing reporters to check out claims that ACA policies are more expensive than current ones.

Also I have heard several people who have managed to register interviewed who point out that shopping in the traditional market was at least as time consuming and more confusing, requiring visits to individual insurance sites to compare apples and oranges. Also you have to answer many more questions abt your healt before you can even get a quote.Funny we never hear just how cumbersome and inefficient the traditional market is.
I don't know why they didn't allow people to explore first, register later. I suppose it's because they wanted to tout how many people they've registered as soon as possible. Little did they know.

Good summary of where the federal government failed but then contracting in the federal government has more problems than just the ACA.    the KISS principle should apply.  Without having to log in or create an account, anyone should be able to put in their age, state of residence, estimated income and get information on plans, costs and subsides.   Kaiser already has a working site to estimate your subsidy and even navigators are recommending it instead of the federal site.  Stop reinventing the wheel.  There are any number of working websites for purchasing products including health insurance.  Work out the sign up details at the end, not the beginning.  Poor design all around with apparently no one in charge.

I never cared for Tim McCarver's style. He is always trying to sound clever, even intellectual, which comes across as showy. And he too often talks in metaphors. But I grant that he does give good game analysis, which comes from experience.

The "silence" of Vin Scully? Are you kidding? Vin never stops reading from those press notes, stuff having nothing to do with the game......(..."he's a big fella, 6 feet 6, 240, the pride of Toadstool, Arkansas......His dad was a policeman and his mom ran the local.....")......

Amen, Mark. Guys like McCarver make me miss Pat Summerall more than I ever thought possible.

Pat called the play (no matter the sport he was covering) and then quietly let us appreciate what had happened in the moment that followed. Even Madden knew when to shut up and just leave the beauty of Pat's silence alone.
"Homerism"? Does that means he roots for the home team. Seems unlikely since i think he's been dropped for being too critical of the home team. good announcer. Bad comment (silly and wrong.)

Sorry, but I'll take the silence of Vin Scully over the Timmy's blathering homerism any day. The only time I ever heard a good McCarver call was during the 1988 NCLS. Tommy Lasorda stormed out to the mound to pay a visit to reliever Jessie Orasco. Half way to the mound Lasorda boomed in a voice loud enough to caught on tape...." Nothing F$%^#Fing happens till you throw a F%$%&^ing strike" McCarver, finally and for the only time in his life was at a loss for more words than necessary...his call......"Oh my"
At least he got it right once.

With the exception of Tony Kubek and Joe Garagiola watching a baseball game prior to the McCarver era was a nuts and bolts experience . McCarver added true color and insight as well as wit. He taught us young fans the inner game without losing sight of the reality that baseball was  about having fun. Hearing him describe Gooden's curveball as" Lord Charles" or a Linda Ronstadt  fastball (blew by you) added a measure of artistry to the story of a game. His legacy stands strong and we fans now have the great  Ron Darling to carry forward the education of the next generation of fans.

Actually, Vin Scully is still calling Dodger games on their radio station, at least this tear. I heard his call of innings 1-3 and 7-9 of one of the NLCS games.  Two other guys, perfectly good announcers, called the middle three innings, but the difference in quality was jarring. Scully remains the best play by play announcer ever, in any sport.
Vin Scully would be interested to know that he's "no more".  He still calls Dodger games.

Tim was a good announcer which is all we ask for. The Vin Scullys and the Red Barbers are no more so the best a fan can hope for is a smart guy who works hard. And if he isn't Dick Vitale so much the better.

OK, multiple studies have shown that the most cost effective and efficient medical systems, in order are:1) Socialized medicine where the government owns the facilities and hires the staff, e.g. Great Britain and our VA. 2) Single payer systems, the government collects taxes and pays the bills of mostly private facilities and providers, e.g., Canada and our Medicare 3) systems where highly regulated not for profit insurance companies sell policies in a regulated system, e.g., Switzerland and to some extent, Hawaii 4) Romney/Obamacare, a mix of for profit insurance/providers/facilities and government programs where a high percentage of the population is covered and 5) our current expensive, inefficient, ineffective and immoral non-system mix of for profit insurance/providers/facillities/pharma and government programs. Said non-system has about 50 million who are not covered by insurance and another 50 million with essentially bogus insurance. Note that in #5 virtually everyone is in the medical bankruptcy pool. Besides the expense, #5 also gives you lousy (as in approaching 3rd world) medical/health statistics.
A recent study by Gerald Friedman, Prof. of Economics at U of Mass, Amherst, shows that the U.S. could cover EVERYONE, for just about everything, in a single payer system and save $592 Billion a year. We could buy a lot of research and innovation for that kind of savings. We'd certainly buy way better health statistics AND get us all out of the medical bankruptcy pool.
Move forward to where?  Right into the giant safety net.  Full speed ahead.

Excess pension fund earnings is just one of a multitude of municipal accounting fantasies. In New York, state mandated municipal accounting hides the cost of every municipal program.

For instance, in our village of 3200, the volunteer fire department’s annual budget is around $400,000, but it’s real cost is $1.3 million. Salaries, consumables and utilities are in the department budget, but bond payments for fire trucks and building improvements, insurances and payroll taxes are elsewhere. The cost of insurance and payroll taxes is lumped together by policy and type of tax, not by department or program incurring the cost.

The state required this to mirror business accounting practices. But where a large corporation has numerous financial employees and officers to advise on costs holistically, villages have only a treasurer who may or may not have financial training. Many of those who do treat their profession like a magician treats his, never explaining the tricks.

Contractors have to be closely supervised for the results to be satisfactory and supervised by someone who cannot be easily fooled by the contractor. Else the contractor will deliver warm bodies in return for our tax dollars. And the couple of sharp executives at the top of the contract company run circles around the bureaucrat (paid 1/10 the salary) who is supposed to monitor the program.

This is a structural problem once you allow the government to engage in large-scale contracting. Because -- for some reason -- the contracts allow the contracting companies to pay so much better than the government jobs that originally existed! And so the talent exits and there is no fox left to guard the hen house (our tax dollars).

As a Prime member, I don't mind increasing the cost on regular shipping. For some of us using Prime, frequent purchases eventually wash out the cost of the shipping. However, if they increased the Prime price, I would reconsider.

But it all comes down to how much you spend and how anxious you are to get the item. If $35 is the threshold, I expect more people will make fewer impulse purchases and hold off finalizing purchases until they have enough to meet limit.

Either way, it is still cheaper than some other websites

"In 2006, per-capita spending for health care in Canada was US$3,678; in the U.S., US$6,714"

"This wouldn’t amount to the full-on push for single payer that some people expect from the left" .....Why is this something that would come from the left? I would argue that the idea of going to single payer should come from everyone who has a brain and can do  basic arithmetic. Affordable healthcare is simple not amenable to the normal constraints of the free market system. It simply isn't. The experiment has run for more than 50 years. In Canada, everyone has health insurance; Canadians live longer than Americans; their infant mortality rate is lower; when polled more Canadians approve of their healthcare system than Americans; and the bottom line is that they pay 40% less per person for their healthcare. If the U.S had the Canadian system, as a country we would save about $800 billion dollars a year. Our annual deficit this year is $600 billion; so we could do everything we are doing right now, balance the budget, and put $200 billion dollars in our pockets. No one can claim that they are interested in saving money; no one can claim that they really care about the deficit, if they are opposed to single payer system. Yes it is big government; forget the stupid dogma - sometimes big government really is better..... P.S., I am an independent.

Businesses simply don't need as many American workers. We can't expect them to hire workers they don't need, nor is it good for workers to be in jobs that are not productive.

The question is what can the government do to encourage businesses to move to a place where they need and/or can utilize more American workers.

It may involve something that hasn't been done before. Some kind of private/public effort to recreate jobs for this particular economy. Most of the usual suspects have already been tried.

Public investment in infrastructure, systems, etc. are possibilities but they would have to be managed very tightly. That would also be new.

Adam. Some interesting proposals. I'll agree with some. I'm a retired federal employee who started working in 1972 for the SCS. Before I really understood the differences between D's and R's. If Libertarians were around I never heard of them. I grew up knowing both D's and R's did that nasty Vietnam War.

So I've been through several different administrations. From my perspective I've seen some similar patterns. I liked Jimmy Carter before he gave us a 9% raise in his re-election year and was astonished a president would court the fed employee vote. I worked through Reagan-Bush-Clinton-Bush-Obama. Reagan surely embarrassed us with his 9 worst words but since we worked with the ag community and helped farmers and ranchers they weren't really hostile. Bush I didn't have much affect. Clinton cut our budget to the point it seemed we needed high authority to get a pencil.

Bush II lavished our agency with new computers, trucks, other equipment and gave farmers and ranchers all kinds of monetary incentives to participate in conservation programs. We didn't get the extra staff to properly plan in the field to design the plans. It was a get it spent attitude. People worked faster with less good field work. Even GWB got a conservation plan for his ranch in Crawford from SCS, now NRCS. Obama froze any COLAs for 2-3 yrs.

I know there's been a dropping federal employee numbers.Even our agency hired private contractors for some larger projects we didn't have staff for.

I think they measured money and I think they missed measuring those who have little money but have excellent knowledge.  Many people educated in the humanities would fit into that group.  It's also difficult to measure children and families who have intense language experience but in a different language.  There is a good deal missing here but they did do a good job of identifying English speaking groups in the culture who will be left behind if intervention isn't initiated early.  I think it would be interesting to do a study of children who have rich language lives in another language. I would hypothesize that those children might well be the ones in their cultural groups who manage to succeed in the USA despite poverty and the inability to speak English during the pre-school years.

There is a study around which discovered that books make huge difference even if parents can't read. Just having books present in the house seems to have a profound effect on children's school success.  The researchers found that families with 500 plus books or college education puts children 3.2 years ahead of their peers without one of the other of those benefits. I think a library association did the study and I'll look around for it.
